questions.text: What is the most appropriate treatment for severe acne?
questions.solution:
Isotretinoin is the most effective treatment for severe, nodulocystic, or treatment-resistant acne. It is a systemic retinoid that reduces sebum production, keratinization, and bacterial colonization, leading to long-term remission in many cases.

Acne Severity

Treatment Options

Mild Acne
  • Over-the-counter topical treatments (benzoyl peroxide, salicylic acid)
  • Topical retinoids (adapalene) (Option A ruled out)

Moderate Acne
  • Topical antibiotics (clindamycin, erythromycin)
  • Oral antibiotics (doxycycline, minocycline)
  • Topical retinoids (Option A ruled out)
  • Hormonal therapy (for females)

Severe Acne
  • Oral isotretinoin (Most effective) (Option B)
  • Oral antibiotics
  • Topical retinoids
  • Hormonal therapy (for females)
  • Intralesional corticosteroids (for cystic acne)


 

Other Options:

 

Steroids (Option C): Not used for acne treatment as systemic steroids can worsen acne (steroid-induced acne). Intralesional steroids can be used on a per lesion basis but is not the most appropriate treatment option to cure severe acne.


Antibiotics (Option D): Topical or oral antibiotics (e.g., doxycycline, clindamycin) are useful for inflammatory acne, but they are not as effective as isotretinoin for severe or resistant cases.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the distinctive finding shown in the image below, which is pathognomonic for Psoriasis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Subungual oil drop sign

Explanation:

  • This sign refers to small, yellowish-orange discolourations seen beneath the nail plate, resembling drops of oil, and is highly specific for nail psoriasis.
  • It is the most specific sign of psoriasis with a specificity of ~98%
  • It occurs due to nail bed parakeratosis and psoriasiform hyperplasia
  • It occurs just before onycholysis

Important findings in nail psoriasis are (Mnemonic: POLISH)

  • Pits
  • Onycholysis
  • Leukonychia
  • Salmon patch (Subungual oil drop sign)
  • Subungual Hyperkeratosis

Incorrect Options:

Nail Pitting (Option A):

  • Although nail pitting is common in psoriasis, it is not pathognomonic, as it can also be seen in alopecia areata and eczema.

Thinning of Nails (Option C):

  • Nail thinning is more commonly associated with lichen planus or trauma-related nail dystrophy, rather than psoriasis.

Pterygium (Option D):

  • Pterygium (dorsal or ventral) occurs due to scarring of the nail matrix, commonly seen in lichen planus, not psoriasis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female comes with complaints of pain in her fingernail. On examination, nail folds were seen to be red and with erythema as shown in the picture. The most likely diagnosis is.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Paronychia

Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis for the described symptoms of a 40-year-old female with pain in her fingernail, along with redness and erythema of the nail folds, is paronychia.

Paronychia:

  • is an infection or inflammation of the skin around the nail, specifically the nail folds.
  • It can occur acutely or chronically.
    • Acute paronychia is typically caused by bacterial infection, often by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes.
    • Chronic paronychia is often associated with fungal infections, particularly Candida species.
  • Symptoms:
    • redness, swelling, tenderness, and pain around the nail.
    • The affected area may also appear warm and may develop pus-filled abscesses.
  • Commonly seen in:
    • Individuals who frequently immerse their hands in water
    • Who engage in activities that cause minor trauma to the skin around the nails, such as nail biting, picking, or manicuring.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Physical examination of the affected area and evaluate the patient's symptoms.
    • a sample of the pus or discharge may be sent for laboratory analysis to determine the causative organism.
  • Treatment:
    • Warm water soaks, topical antibiotic ointments or creams, and, if necessary, oral antibiotics.
    • In cases of chronic paronychia associated with fungal infection, antifungal medications.
    • In some instances, incision and drainage of abscesses may be required.

Incorrect Options:

Yellow-nail syndrome (Option B): is a condition characterized by yellowish discoloration, thickening, and slow growth of the nails. It is usually associated with underlying respiratory or lymphatic disorders and is not consistent with the described symptoms.

Psoriasis (Option C): is a chronic inflammatory skin condition that can affect the nails, causing pitting, discoloration, separation of the nail from the nail bed (onycholysis), and thickening of the nails.

Alopecia areata (Option D): is an autoimmune condition characterized by hair loss, typically in patches. It does not involve the nails and is not related to the described symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the morpholine drugs listed below is used as a nail lacquer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Amorolfine

Explanation:

  • Amorolfine is an antifungal medication that belongs to the class of drugs known as morpholines. It is commonly used as a topical nail lacquer for the treatment of fungal infections of the nails, known as onychomycosis.
  • Amorolfine works by inhibiting the growth of fungi, including dermatophytes and yeasts, which are responsible for causing nail infections.
  • Morpholines are a class of organic compounds that contain a morpholine ring structure, which is a saturated heterocycle consisting of a six-membered ring with one oxygen atom and one nitrogen atom. These compounds have diverse applications in the field of pharmaceuticals due to their unique chemical properties.

 

Incorrect Options:

Oxiconazole (Option B): Oxiconazole is not the correct choice for the drug belonging to the morpholines and used as a nail lacquer. It is an antifungal medication, but it belongs to a different class of drugs called imidazoles. Oxiconazole is available in various formulations, including creams and lotions, and is used for the treatment of various fungal skin infections.

Ciclopirox olamine (Option C): Ciclopirox olamine is not the correct choice for the drug belonging to the morpholines and used as a nail lacquer. Although it is an antifungal medication, it belongs to a different class of drugs called hydroxypyridones. Ciclopirox olamine is available as a nail lacquer and is used for the treatment of fungal infections of the nails, including onychomycosis.

Tioconazole (Option D): Tioconazole is not the correct choice for the drug belonging to the morpholines and used as a nail lacquer. It is an antifungal medication that belongs to the class of drugs called imidazoles. Tioconazole is commonly used for the treatment of vaginal yeast infections and is available in various formulations, including creams and ointments.

questions.text: A young woman has presented to the OPD with facial symptoms (acne or pimple-like lesions). Which of the following options will not be effective for treating these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Topical fluocinolone

Explanation:

  • Fluocinolone is a topical corticosteroid, which is not recommended for acne.
  • Corticosteroids can worsen acne by promoting follicular occlusion, increasing sebum production, and causing steroid-induced acne.
  • Acne treatment focuses on reducing inflammation, controlling bacterial overgrowth, and regulating keratinisation, which fluocinolone does not address.
  • Acne vulgaris is a chronic inflammatory condition affecting the pilosebaceous units.

Pathophysiology:

  1. Increased sebum production (hormonal influence).
  2. Follicular hyperkeratinisation (plug formation).
  3. Bacterial colonisation (Cutibacterium acnes proliferation).
  4. Inflammation (leading to papules, pustules, nodules).

Treatment Approach:

Type of Acne

Treatment

Comedonal acne

Topical retinoids (tretinoin, adapalene, tazarotene)

Mild inflammatory acne

Topical benzoyl peroxide, topical antibiotics (clindamycin, erythromycin)

Moderate-severe acne

Oral antibiotics (doxycycline, minocycline), combination therapy

Severe nodulocystic acne

Oral isotretinoin (vitamin A derivative)

 

Why Steroids Are Not Recommended:

  • Topical corticosteroids (like fluocinolone) can lead to:
    • Steroid-induced acne (monomorphic papules, no comedones).
    • Skin atrophy and telangiectasia with long-term use.
    • Rebound flare-ups upon discontinuation.

 

Topical benzoyl peroxide (Option A) is incorrect because benzoyl peroxide is an effective first-line treatment for acne. It has antibacterial properties (against Cutibacterium acnes), reduces inflammation, and prevents antibiotic resistance when used with topical antibiotics.

Topical tazarotene (Option C) is incorrect because tazarotene is a topical retinoid that promotes keratinocyte turnover, prevents comedone formation, and reduces acne lesions. It is highly effective in treating acne.

Topical antibiotics (Option D) is incorrect because antibiotics like clindamycin and erythromycin reduce C. acnes growth and inflammation. They are commonly used in combination with benzoyl peroxide to prevent resistance.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a 35-year-old male who is experiencing hair loss, based on the provided examination findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Alopecia areata

Explanation:

  • Given the patchy nature of the hair loss, alopecia areata is the most likely diagnosis.

 

Alopecia areata:

Alopecia areata is a T-cell-mediated autoimmune condition targeting the anagen hair bulb causing non-scarring hair loss. Clinical features include,

  • Localized patches of hair loss on the scalp that emerge over a few weeks. It can also affect other areas, such as the beard, eyebrows, eyelashes, and extremities.
  • Variants:
    • Alopecia Totalis: Complete hair loss from the scalp.
    • Alopecia Universalis: Complete hair loss from all over the body.
    • Ophiasis: Occipital hair loss.

  

 

  • Exclamation-mark hair, with a narrower proximal end than the distal end, is commonly observed at the periphery of lesions and is a pathognomonic finding in patients with alopecia areata.
  • Pitting of nails that is superficial, geometric and regular

 

Non-scarring alopecia

Exclamation mark hair

Regular nail pitting

 

The pull test is positive, Very gentle traction on the unaffected hair at the margin of the patch of hair loss can remove all of the hair from the roots painlessly. It is a distinguishing feature of alopecia areata

Tinea capitis (Scalp Ringworm) (Option A):

  • Fungal infection of the scalp, common in children.
  • Presents with scaly patches, broken hairs, and black dots (not smooth bald patches).
  • KOH mount shows fungal hyphae.
  • Can progress to kerion (severe inflammatory form).

Kerion (Option B):

  • Severe inflammatory form of tinea capitis with painful, boggy swelling, pustules, and abscesses.
  • Often associated with secondary bacterial infection.
  • More common in children.

Androgenic alopecia (Male Pattern Baldness) (Option D):

  • Gradual thinning of hair in a defined pattern (bitemporal recession, vertex baldness).
  • Hormone-related (DHT sensitivity).
  • No well-defined patches of baldness.

questions.text:
A disorder is characterized by recurrent hair-pulling resulting in noticeable hair loss. Which of the following statements about this disorder is not accurate?

[

choices.text: The onset is typically in adolescence or early adulthood
Associated with feelings of pleasure or relief after hair-pulling
Caused by a bacterial infection of the scalp

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Caused by a bacterial infection of the scalp

Explanation:

  • The disorder depicted in the image appears to be Trichotillomania (Hair-Pulling Disorder), which is characterized by recurrent hair-pulling leading to hair loss.
  • Trichotillomania is not due to a bacterial infection but rather a psychiatric disorder

Trichotillomania:

  • It is a psychiatric disorder in which obsessive, recurrent pulling of one’s hair results in hair loss (Options A, C)
  • It is seen in adolescents or young adults, more commonly in girls (Option B)
  • Patchy hair loss with broken hair of variable lengths is seen in commonly accessible sites like the frontoparietal area of the scalp.
  • In the Friar Tuck sign or Tonsure pattern, there is uneven hair loss in a circular pattern with surrounding hairs remaining unaffected.

 

  • Perifollicular haemorrhages can also be seen because of trauma to the scalp.
  • Skin biopsy shows empty hair follicles, with some forming soft twisted hairs described as tracheomalacia.
  • Treatment includes cognitive behavioural therapy and antipsychotic medications like SSRI and paroxetine.

questions.text:
Which of the following factors is responsible for non-scarring alopecia in patients?

1. Alopecia areata

2. Telogen effluvium

3. Androgenic alopecia

4. Frontal fibrosing alopecia
questions.solution:
• Non-scarring alopecia refers to hair loss without permanent follicular destruction, meaning hair regrowth is possible.
  • Alopecia areata (immune-mediated hair follicle attack), Telogen effluvium (stress-induced shedding), and Androgenic alopecia (genetic hair thinning) are all non-scarring causes.
  • Frontal fibrosing alopecia (FFA) is a scarring alopecia, meaning it causes permanent hair loss with fibrosis.

Non-Scarring vs. Scarring Alopecia:

Feature

Non-Scarring Alopecia

Scarring Alopecia

Pathophysiology

Hair follicles remain intact; regrowth is possible.

Follicular destruction with fibrosis; irreversible loss.

Examples

Alopecia areata (autoimmune)

Telogen effluvium (stress-related shedding)

Androgenic alopecia (hormonal, genetic)

Frontal fibrosing alopecia (FFA) (lichen planopilaris variant) (Option 4 ruled out)

Lupus erythematosus

Folliculitis decalvans

Clinical Findings

Smooth scalp, no scarring

Can have exclamation mark hairs (alopecia areata)

Inflammation, erythema, follicular plugging

Scalp atrophy or fibrosis

Prognosis

Usually reversible

Permanent hair loss

Treatment

Alopecia areata: Intralesional steroids, JAK inhibitors

Telogen effluvium: Treat underlying cause

Androgenic alopecia: Minoxidil, finasteride

Frontal fibrosing alopecia: Immunosuppressants, topical corticosteroids

questions.text: A lady developed a skin reaction, as shown in the image after using a hair dye. Which of the following chemicals is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) p-Phenylenediamine

Explanation:

  • p-Phenylenediamine (PPD) is a chemical commonly found in hair dyes. It is known to cause allergic reactions in some people, and symptoms can include itching, redness, swelling, and skin blistering. PPD allergies are fairly common and can be quite severe, so it is important to be cautious when using hair dyes that contain this chemical.

Incorrect Options:

Pollen (Option A): Pollen is a common allergen that can cause allergic reactions like hay fever. However, it is not typically found in hair dyes, so it is unlikely to be the cause of a skin reaction from hair dye.

Chromates (Option B): Chromates are chemicals that are sometimes used in hair dyes. They cause allergic reactions in some people, especially those with a history of eczema or other skin conditions. Symptoms of a chromate allergy can include itching, redness, and skin swelling.

Balsam of Peru (Option C): Balsam of Peru is a fragrance commonly used in perfumes, cosmetics, and other personal care products. It is known to cause allergic reactions in some people, and symptoms can include itching, redness, and skin swelling. However, it is not typically found in hair dyes.

questions.text: Where is the apocrine gland present?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Axilla

Explanation:

  • Apocrine secretion involves the release of cellular products along with portions of the cytoplasm.
  • Apocrine sweat glands present in the axilla, perineum, and groin regions secrete their secretion into hail follicles by apocrine mechanism and are primarily responsible for producing body odour.
  • The mammary gland (Modified apocrine gland) produces milk by apocrine secretion.

Types of glandular secretion

 

Merocrine

Apocrine

Holocrine

Mechanism

By exocytosis

The apical part of the cell is pinched off.

Whole-cell is disintegrated while secretion

Examples

Eccrine sweat glands.

Salivary glands.

Globlet cells.

Apocrine sweat glands.

Mammary glands.

Sebaceous glands

 

Palm and soles (Option A)

  • The palms and soles are free of apocrine glands.
  • These areas primarily contain eccrine sweat glands, which are responsible for thermoregulation through merocrine secretion.

Face (Option B)

  • While the face contains sebaceous glands and eccrine sweat glands, apocrine glands are absent from the face.
  • The sebaceous glands in the face use holocrine secretion to release sebum, not apocrine mechanisms.

Scalp (Option D)

  • While the scalp has eccrine sweat glands and sebaceous glands, apocrine glands are not located on the scalp.

questions.text:
Which of the following conditions causes non-scarring alopecia?

1. Alopecia areata

2. Telogen effluvium

3. Androgenic alopecia

4. Folliculitis Decalvans
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1, 2 and 3

Explanation:

Cicatricial alopecias

Non-cicatricial alopecias

Loss of hair follicle stem cells

Stem cells are not affected

Irreversible cessation of hair cycle

Damage to hair cycle can be reversed

Dermoscopy: Absent follicular ostia

Dermoscopy: Ostia are present. Black dots may be seen

Examples:

  • Frontal fibrosing alopecia.
  • Folliculitis.
  • Lupus erythematosus
  • Scleroderma

Types:

  • Patterned: Androgenetic alopecia
  • Diffuse: Effluvium
  • Patchy:
    • Alopecia areata,
    • Trichotillomania.
    • Tinea capitis,
    • Moth-eaten alopecia

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Correct Optlon B- 1, 2 and 3:

1. Alopecia areata:

  • Alopecia areata is an autoimmune condition that can cause non-scarring alopecia. It typically presents as well-defined, round or oval patches of hair loss on the scalp or other areas of the body. While it can lead to non-scarring alopecia, in some cases, it may progress to involve the entire scalp or body, resulting in complete hair loss.

2. Telogen effluvium:

  • Telogen effluvium is a form of non-scarring alopecia characterized by diffuse hair shedding. It occurs when a large number of hair follicles enter the telogen (resting) phase simultaneously, leading to increased hair loss. It is often triggered by various factors such as childbirth, surgery, illness, or significant stress.

3. Androgenic alopecia:

  • Androgenic alopecia, also known as male-pattern baldness or female-pattern baldness, is a genetic condition that leads to progressive hair thinning. It is a common cause of non-scarring alopecia, especially in a specific pattern on the scalp.

Folllculltis Decalvans (Option D): Folliculitis decalvans is a type of scarring alopecia. Folliculitis decalvans typically presents as clusters of small, red, inflamed papules or pustules atthe site of hair follicles, often accompanied by crusting and scaling. Over time, the affected area may progress to form patches of smooth, bald skin with visible scarring.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated wIth non-scarring alopecia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Frontal fibrosing alopecia

Explanation:

Frontal fibrosing alopecia is scarring alopecia, not non-scarring. It leads to permanent hair loss due to fibrosis and destruction of hair follicles, unlike non-scarring alopecia, where hair loss is reversible if the underlying cause is addressed.

Cicatricial alopecias

Non-cicatricial alopecias

Loss of hair follicle stem cells

Stem cells are not affected

Irreversible cessation of hair cycle

Damage to hair cycle can be reversed

Dermoscopy: Absent follicular ostia

Dermoscopy: Ostia are present. Black dots may be seen

Examples:

  • Frontal fibrosing alopecia.
  • Folliculitis.
  • Lupus erythematosus
  • Scleroderma

Types:

  • Patterned: Androgenetic alopecia (Option B)
  • Diffuse: Effluvium (Option D)
  • Patchy:
    • Alopecia areata (Option A)
    • Trichotillomania
    • Tinea capitis
    • Moth-eaten alopecia

Telogen Effluvium (Option D) is hair loss triggered by physical stressors like surgery, trauma, or illnesses such as dengue, malaria, COVID-19, TB, or chikungunya. TE can also occur during pregnancy, known as Telogen gravidarum.

  • Here, stress causes hair follicles to prematurely enter the resting phase (Telogen) instead of the growth phase (Anagen), leading to hair shedding after about three months.
  • Chronic TE can be caused by factors like iron deficiency, thyroid disorders, crash dieting, or malnutrition. Prolonged exposure to stressors can result in long-term hair loss.

questions.solution:

questions.text: What is the most effective drug to prescribe for a 25-year-old male patient with acne, as shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Systemic isotretinoin

Explanation:

The photo shows moderate to severe inflammatory acne, characterised by:

  • Numerous papules, pustules, and nodules

  • Scarring and crusting on the lower cheek

  • Evidence of nodulocystic lesions

This type of acne is not responsive to only topical therapies or oral antibiotics in the long term.

Systemic isotretinoin is the most effective treatment for:

  • Severe, nodulocystic acne

  • Acne with scarring

  • Acne that has failed oral antibiotics

  • Acne with significant psychological impact

It works by:

  • Reducing sebaceous gland size and sebum production

  • Normalising keratinisation

  • Reducing inflammation and Cutibacterium acnes colonisation

 

Topical tretinoin (Option A): is incorrect because it is insufficient alone for this level of severity. Used in mild acne or as adjunct.

 

Systemic doxycycline (Option B): is incorrect because while effective in moderate inflammatory acne, it does not adequately control nodulocystic or scarring acne like in the image.

 

Systemic minocycline (Option C): is also a systemic antibiotic alternative to doxycycline but offers no major benefit over doxycycline and has more side effects (e.g., drug-induced lupus, pigmentation).

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with a focal area of hair loss accompanied by scaling and itching, as shown in the image. The child’s sibling had a similar condition two years ago. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tinea:

  • The child’s focal hair loss, scaling, and itching, along with the history of a similar condition in a sibling, are consistent with tinea capitis, a fungal infection of the scalp.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Alopecia areata: Causes smooth, well-defined patches of hair loss without scaling or itching.

Option C - Pyoderma: A bacterial skin infection that typically presents with pustules or ulcers, not scaling.

Option D - Pediculosis capitis: Head lice infestation, characterized by itching and nits, not focal hair loss with scaling.

questions.solution:

questions.text: An elderly female undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer is experiencing significant hair loss. What is the most likely cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
The most likely cause of significant hair loss in an elderly female undergoing chemotherapy is Anagen Effluvium. This type of hair loss occurs due to damage to the hair follicle during the anagen (growth) phase. It is commonly caused by chemotherapy, radiation therapy, or toxic agents that impair rapidly dividing cells, including hair follicle matrix cells. Hair loss is usually sudden, diffuse, and non-scarring, occurring within days to weeks after starting chemotherapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Telogen Effluvium (Option A): A temporary hair loss condition caused by stress, illness, or hormonal changes, leading to excessive shedding in the telogen (resting) phase. It is not a primary side effect of chemotherapy.

 

Trichotillomania (Option B): A psychiatric disorder characterized by compulsive hair pulling, leading to patchy hair loss with irregular borders. It is behavioral rather than treatment-induced.


Alopecia Areata (Option C): An autoimmune condition that causes sudden, patchy hair loss due to immune system attacks on hair follicles. It is unrelated to chemotherapy.

questions.text: A 10 year old child presents with hair loss. The hair loss is patchy as shown in the image below.  Which off the following types of tinea is this child suffering from ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Ectothrix:

  • Ectothrix is a type of tinea capitis where the fungal infection primarily affects the outer layer of the hair shaft. This results in hair becoming brittle, breaking off at the surface of the scalp, and causing patchy hair loss.
  • In Ectothrix infections, the fungus can often be seen surrounding the hair shaft on microscopy.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Endothrix:

  • In Endothrix infections, the fungus is found inside the hair shaft and doesn't typically cause hair breakage or patchy hair loss.

Option C - Kerion:

  • Kerion is a severe type of fungal infection of the scalp characterized by painful, boggy, inflamed, and pus-filled nodules or plaques.

Option D - Favus:

  • Favus is a specific type of tinea capitis caused by the fungus Trichophyton schoenleinii. It results in the formation of yellow, cup-shaped crusts on the scalp, along with hair loss.

questions.text: 1st line treatment for acne and comedones should be:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Topical retinoids:

  • Being a chronic inflammatory disease of pilosebaceous units, acne is characterized by the formation of comedones, erythematous papules, and pustules. Generally, the first-line treatment for acne is topical retinoids as they are very much effective against comedones and other inflammatory acne.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Topical steroids: The treatment of acne with topical steroids is highly contraindicated as steroids aggravate the acne in many cases. Also in cases of children, it is generally not prescribed.

Option B - Topical antibiotics: Though antibiotics are used in the treatment of acne, compared to the topical retinoids used in the 1st line management of acne comedones these topical antibiotics are used up, particularly in cases involving inflammatory acne.

Option D - Benzoyl peroxide: The treatment with benzoyl peroxide is not at all applicable for sensitive skin as it gets dried more easily and thus leads to skin irritation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female – pain in the fingernail, on examination nail fold is seen with pus, most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Paronychia:

  • Paronychia is a condition characterized by inflammation and infection of the nail fold
  • It can result from bacterial or fungal infection or trauma to the nail fold.
  • The symptoms of paronychia often include pain, swelling, redness, and the presence of pus around the nail fold.

​​​​​​​

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Yellow nail syndrome: Yellow nail syndrome is a rare condition characterized by yellowing, thickening, and slow growth of the nails.

Option B - Psoriasis: Psoriasis can affect the nails, causing changes such as pitting, thickening, or separation from the nail bed, it is not typically associated with pain in the fingernail.

Option C - Alopecia Areata: Alopecia areata does not directly affect the nails or the nail fold.

questions.text: What is the common association with the condition depicted below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Pitting of nails:

  • Pitting of nails is a classic finding in alopecia areata. It refers to the presence of small, shallow depressions or indentations on the nail surface. Pitting is thought to result from the localized inflammation affecting the nail matrix in alopecia areata.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Oil drop sign: The oil drop sign is a characteristic finding in psoriasis, not in alopecia areata..

Option B - Leukonychia striata: Leukonychia striata is commonly associated with trauma, nutritional deficiencies, or certain systemic conditions, but not specifically with alopecia areata.

Option C - Pterygium of nails: Pterygium refers to the abnormal overgrowth of the proximal nail fold onto the nail plate.t it is not typically associated with alopecia areata.

questions.text: A patient presents with multiple nodulocystic lesions on the face. Which among the following is the drug of choice in this condition ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Isotretinoin:

  • When a patient presents with multiple nodulocystic lesions on the face, the drug of choice for this condition is Isotretinoin.
  • This condition is known as severe or nodulocystic acne, and Isotretinoin is considered the most effective treatment option for this type of acne.
  • Isotretinoin is a retinoid medication that is derived from vitamin A. It works by reducing the size and activity of the sebaceous glands, which are responsible for producing excess oil that contributes to the development of acne. Isotretinoin also has anti-inflammatory properties, helping to reduce inflammation associated with nodulocystic acne

 

Incorrect Options:

 Option A - Steroids:

  • Steroids may be used in certain cases when there is a need to rapidly reduce inflammation, but they are not the preferred long-term treatment option.

Option C - Erythromycin:

  • Erythromycin is not the drug of choice for nodulocystic acne. Erythromycin is more commonly used as part of combination therapy

Option D - Tetracycline:

  • Tetracycline is not the drug of choice for nodulocystic acne.
